contextId.information: Paul speaks of the Holy Spirit as if he were a place in which the believers were located. AT: "how the Holy Spirit has enabled you to love believers" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: your love in the Spirit

contextId.information: Paul speaks of the Colossian believers as though they were containers. AT: "that God will fill you with what you need to know so that you can do his will" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: that you will be filled with the knowledge of his will

contextId.information: Walking here signifies behavior in life. AT: "that you will live the way God expects you to" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: that you will walk worthily of the Lord

contextId.information: Paul is speaking of the Colossian believers as if they were trees or plants. As a plant grows and bears fruit, so also believers are to keep getting to know God better and doing good deeds. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: will bear fruit

contextId.information: Paul speaks of the Colossian believers as if God would move them into a location of perseverance and patience. In reality, he is praying that they will never stop trusting in God and that they will be completely patient as they honor him. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: into all perseverance and patience

contextId.information: Receiving what God has promised believers is spoken of as if it were inheriting property and wealth from a family member. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: inheritance

contextId.information: Darkness is a common picture in the scriptures for evil. AT: "the power of evil" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the dominion of darkness

contextId.information: Paul often speaks as if the believers were "in" Jesus Christ or "in" God. Here this expression can also be translated as "by means of his Son we have redemption."  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: In his Son we have redemption

contextId.information: Here "image" does not mean a representation of something that is visible. Instead, "image" here means that by knowing the Son, we learn what God the Father is like.  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: The Son is the image of the invisible God

contextId.information: "The Son is the firstborn." The expression "firstborn Son" does not refer to Jesus' birth in Bethlehem. Instead, it refers to the Son's position as the eternal Son of God the Father. In this sense, "firstborn" is a metaphor meaning "most important." Jesus is the most important and the unique "Son" of God. He is God. The word "Son" shows Jesus' intimate relationship with the Father. That relationship cannot be understood until and unless you use your language's words for "son" and "father."  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: He is the firstborn

contextId.information: Paul is describing the Colossians as though Jesus had physically cleaned them, put them in clean clothes, and brought them to stand before God the Father. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: to present you holy, blameless, and above reproach before him

contextId.information: This expression of location stands for "in God's view" or "in God's mind" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: before him

contextId.information: Paul speaks of his body as if it were a container that could hold suffering. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I fill up in my flesh

contextId.information: This means to bring about the purpose of God's gospel message, which is that it be preached and believed. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: to fulfill the word of God

contextId.information: Paul speaks of the value of this secret truth about God as if it were a treasure of material wealth. "riches" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the riches of the glory of this secret truth

contextId.information: Paul speaks of the believers as if they were actual containers in which Christ is present. This is one of his ways of expressing the union of the believers with Christ. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Christ is in you

contextId.information: Paul speaks of a person who is completely sure that the good news is true as though that person were rich in physical things. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: all the riches of full assurance of understanding

contextId.information: Paul speaks of a person with true faith in Christ as if that person were a tree growing in solid ground with deep roots. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Be firmly planted in him

contextId.information: Paul speaks of thanksgiving as if it were objects that a person could obtain more of. AT: "be very thankful to God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: abound in thanksgiving

contextId.information: Paul speaks of the way a person can believe false teachings (because they believe false things or love the wrong things) as if someone had physically caught and held that person by force. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: captures you

contextId.information: Paul speaks of false ideas that produce nothing and so are without value as though they are containers with nothing in them. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: empty deceit

contextId.information: Paul speaks of the way God forgives our sins as if it were the way a person, to whom many people owe money or goods, destroys the record of that debt so they do not have to pay him back. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: He erased the written record of debts and the regulations that were against us

contextId.information: In Roman times, it was common practice for the Roman armies to have a victory parade when they returned home, displaying all the prisoners they had captured and goods they had obtained. God was victorious over the  evil powers and authorities. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: he made a public spectacle of them

contextId.information: A shadow gives only a vague idea of the shape and nature of an object. In a similar way, religious traditions such as the law of Moses can only partially show the reality of Jesus Christ. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: a shadow of the things to come

contextId.information: Here Paul refers to false teachers as if they were corrupt judges at an athletic contest who would unjustly disqualify the believers from winning the prizes they deserve, and he speaks of Christ saving a person as if Christ were giving a prize to the winner of such a contest. AT: "Let no one ... disqualify you from winning a prize" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Let no one ... judge you out of your prize

contextId.information: Here Paul  speaks about people who claim to have dreams and visions from God and who talk proudly about them. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: enters into the things he has seen

contextId.information: Here a person who boasts is spoken of as if he were an object into which someone had blown air to make it larger than it should be. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: puffed up

contextId.information: Paul speaks of trusting Christ as though one were grasping Christ with one's hands. AT: "He does not firmly grasp" or "He does not cling to," just as a child firmly holds on to his parent. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: He does not hold on to

contextId.information: As God has raised Christ to heaven, so God counts the believers in Colossae as though he has also raised them to heaven. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: God has raised you with Christ

contextId.information: As Christ actually died, so God counts the Colossian believers as having died with Christ. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: For you have died

contextId.information: Paul speaks of sinful desires as though they were the body parts people use to satisfy them. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Put to death, then, the members that are on earth

contextId.information: Paul speaks of the way a person behaves as if it were a road or path a person walks on. AT: "These are the things you used to do"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: It is in these things that you also once walked

contextId.information: As a person puts on clothing when getting dressed, believers are to show mercy and other moral qualities in their behavior toward each other. The lower intestines were often thought to be the center of emotions of mercy and compassion. Translators will probably have to change this figure of speech in their versions. AT: "Be merciful at all times" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:bita_manmade]])
contextId.quote: Put on ... intestines of mercy

contextId.information: Paul speaks of Christ's word as if it were a person capable of living inside other people. "Always trust Christ's promises" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Let the word of Christ live in you

contextId.information: Receiving what God has promised believers is spoken of as if it were inheriting property and wealth from a family member. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: inheritance

contextId.information: "God would provide opportunities" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: God would open a door

contextId.information: The idea of walking is often used for the idea of conducting one's life. AT: "Live in such a way that those who are not believers will see that you are wise" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Walk in wisdom toward those outside

contextId.information: Food with salt is a metaphor for words that teach others and that others enjoy hearing. "Let your conversation always be gracious and attractive" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Let your words always be with grace. Let them be seasoned with salt
